address.street: Marielle Apartments, 3, Magrath Road, Ashok Nagar
Marielle Apartments, 3, Magrath Road, Ashok Nagar

content.description: No Ardbeg! Monday evening, a mid-July drizzle outside, CSNY set to a hum, clutches of people in the sparse interiors of the whisky bar at the stately ITC Gardenia in the heart of town. And there’s no Ardbeg. “It’s fast-moving,” croons the mannerly steward (a note above the “Woodstock” refrain), and hands over the menu – a tome-sized “dossier”, as they call it here, which you wouldn’t normally need if you knew exactly what you wanted. But there was no Ardbeg. That dossier actually befits its given name, packing in a crash course for whisky noobs, with over a hundred blends (which would say a lot for the bar, if only they weren’t out of Ardbeg), each marked with ratings and notes on nose, palate and finish. The Highlands, for instance, named with such delicate twirls of the tongue as Aberfeldy and Aberlour, the Speysides of Cardhu and Glenlivet (ranging from Rs 475 to Rs 1,500 a pour) fetch Highland Nectar ratings between 84 and 89 out of 100. Also on offer are the Lowlands, the Americans (Jack, Jim or John, if you’ve known them long enough; Rs 375-600), the Canadian and the Irish. A stand-alone list (or chapter, if you like) has Teacher’s, Dewar’s, Cutty Sark, Chivas and Ballantine’s (Rs 325 and above). An epilogue marked “rare” highlights curiosities like the Bruichladdich 40YO (Rs 20,000), although the epic prices to note are among the wines, where deglutitions of the Armand De Brignac (blanc or rosé) can be fetched for, no kidding, Rs 1,58,000 a carafe. A selection of Cohibas and Churchills (Rs 1,400-1,500 a piece, of varying ring gauges and sizes) will have you stepping out to the hotel’s airy Lotus Pavilion to spark a fire. And the bacon wraps of manchego and prunes (Rs 425) from the short eats section are a good way to begin. At some point, however, you find that a dossier of this kind would have to carry embellished descriptions of even the humble Old Monk: “velvet smooth dark rum with a hint of vanilla” (Rs 275 a peg; a full bottle retails for Rs 250 at the local “wine” store). But you don’t come here for Old Monk: it’s the Islay line of single malts that you ought to be paying attention to. That’s where the ratings reach the high-90 levels, especially a certain Ardbeg, with its nose of sweet peat, coal and faint floral notes, laden with hints of pepper and chilli, a mellow palate that gives way to sweeping spices and a long, warming finesse. But Ardbeg we didn’t get. So we looked to its consorts – Bowmore, Caol Ila and the Bunnahabhain, the last of which is what we finally decided upon. Twelve years old and rated 84, the Bunnahabhain, true to the dossier, was “remarkably fresh, a tad sweet, and resonant of sea-air, with a clean nutty-malty sweetness”.- Jignes Shah

Once upon a time, Athena was a good place to assume the manner of a judge on So you Think you can Dance. There were people who could shimmy like pros and made their partners look like they wore really nice shoes to hide their two left feet. There was the group of women who insisted on dancing Bollywood-style to house. There was the circle of friends who enthusiastically pranced around and made everyone else yelp and jump out of their way. There was the couple that was literally joined at the hip and bobbed together from left to right like some strange two-headed organism. Today, the amount paid at the entrance on Fridays and Saturdays ranges from Rs 1,000 for a couple to Rs 1,500 for stags and Rs 500 for women. It’s only partly redeemable, so a little more dough has to be shelled out at the bar for a large drink. That has seen to it that the club isn’t packed to the armpits anymore, but it does have some of the energetic buzz of yore, and the blue and red test tube shooters are still ferried around the large room. Maybe that’s enough for a really quick jig in these times. Debaushree Dutta

address.street: John Nagar, opposite BDA Complex, Koramangala
John Nagar, opposite BDA Complex, Koramangala
The Taj West End, Race Course Road
The Taj West End, Race Course Road

content.description: “If you are looking for perfect safety, you will do well to sit on a fence and watch the birds; but if you really wish to learn, you must mount a machine and become acquainted with its tricks by actual trial.” This quote by Wilbur Wright is inspiring enough whether one wants to invent a contraption that will change the way the world travels, or venture, rather gingerly, like Mulder and Scully working on an X-file, into a spacecraft-styled pub that has the distinction of being the oldest in Bangalore (prior to becoming “Bangalore’s hi-tech beer club”, it opened as “The Pub” in 1986). Assure the waiter that a “couples table” isn’t required (there is no cordoning off of the section to ensure any privacy or safety anyway). The menu must be applauded for its creatively-named headers, like “liquefied inflammable” and “to achieve zero gravity”. The beer (`70 for a tap), kalmi kabab (`200) and French fries (`60) should now be called for with Mulder-like enthusiasm; with Scully-like scepticism, all three are peered at since the neon light overhead casts an eerie greenish glow on everything, especially the oil seeping from the kalmi kabab. Thankfully, the beer’s fine and it can be chugged to hip-hop numbers like “Where’s the love” and “In da club”, while reading quotes from Wright or Arthur C Clarke on the wall - DD

address.street: Seven Hotel, Outer Ring Road, Doddanekundi
Seven Hotel, Outer Ring Road, Doddanekundi

content.description: The first section at Pink Sky Bar is for the loner who wants to nurse his drink and soulfully look into the middle distance, or distractedly flip through a book. This area contains a rag-tag assemblage of 1960s-inspired minimalist furniture against pink-toned walls and dark-wood bookshelves stacked with books on art, architecture, design and photography. Here, you must sip on a red Russian (`250) – a tall glass holding a concoction of vodka, lime wedges and pomegranate seeds. Its zesty citrus flavour marries the sweet-tanginess of pomegranate splendidly and is a perfect accompaniment to aimless scanning through any of the books that line the shelves. The second section is the bar – straight out of Mr Freeze’s hideout in Batman & Robin. It has white textured walls, the only colour relief being the pista-green shirts of the bartenders, and the blue and pink spotlights filter through the various liquor bottles propped up like art on the walls. Leaning on the bar, you can take in large gulps of the whiskey sour (`250), while talking to a friend or a bartender, and pincer a shrimp from the delicious Cajun spicy shrimps (`250). The third section is for the large bunch of friends (or even a cosy twosome, actually, with large sofas softened with pillows of lurid pink and fluorescent orange, and dark-wood separators giving an illusion of privacy that allows for free-flowing conversations). Order a plate of lamb spears (`275), and remember to squeeze generous amounts of lime on the juicy chunks of mutton. The drinks at the lounge can work as pick-up lines as well; if you’re looking to woo her, get a between the sheets (`275) – a heady mix of light rum, brandy, triple sec and lemon juice. And if she wants to say no, there’s maiden’s prayer (`250), a strong cocktail of gin, brandy, triple sec and lemon juice - Joshua Muyiwa

Getting to the heartland of Haryana from Bangalore isn’t as circuitous as you’d imagine. Get to Museum Road off MG Road, stop by the hotel called Museum Inn and take the elevator. Reach the top floor. Up here, bang in the middle of the terrace, two floors above the pub The Tavern Inn, is a crossroad junction. Chandigarh, the sign says, is 108 km to the north, Ludhiana farther up at 306 km, Ambala the other way at 180 km, and Bhatinda to the west at 342 km. Set around this sign are a few tables, a few charpoys on one end, and an open tandoor kitchen. You can watch your tandoor bread order being rolled, flung in the air, twirled and baked as you settle down to enjoy some of the more satisfying north Indian fare this city has to offer – great tandoori chicken, succulent kababs and flaky, delicate rotis – all of which warrant repeated visits

Be sure to wear footwear with non-slip soles when you visit Giridhar Bhagatram’s shop on Commercial Street. The floor has been rendered ghee-slick by the millions of feet bearing vats of gulab jamuns since the store opened to the paying public in 1948. But no one seems to care; they come here not for the ambience but for the golden-brown gulab jamuns bobbing gaily in the warm syrup. According to Bhagatram, whose father started the shop in 1948, they sell 30,000 pieces of gulab jamun in a day. They are always served hot and the massive kadai empties out even before the last piece of sweet reaches room temperature – only to be replenished at lightning speed

address.street: Third Floor, Max Mueller Bhavan, 716, CMH Road
Third Floor, Max Mueller Bhavan, 716, CMH Road

content.description: Sunday brunches at Max are easily among the best in town. Arathi and Axel Schorlemmer serve up an impressive spread of bratwurst, baked vegetables and even the occasional prawn curry, with a choice of fresh coleslaw, beetroot, carrot, or potato salads. Navigating through the nosh at a languid pace is recommended; give the hefty bratwurst some special attention and remember to leave some space for dessert. Sweet endings include home-style apple strudel, a rustic cheesecake and marble cake. Best days to visit are Wednesday for the cold salad buffet, and Sunday for the hot brunch; it’s á la carte on all other days

The mud cake here was created to bless all chocoholics for their devotion. The cake shell gives up a warm river of chocolate at the slightest nudge, and sharing dessert no longer remains an option. However, if you’re in need of a full meal with filling entrées, order the fish and chips with an extra helping of potatoes and tartar sauce. The generous portion of fillet is crumb-fried perfectly, though a bit under-seasoned, and the potato chips retain form till the end. Or you could try the Thai red curry with steamed rice. The dish is a winner just given the size of its portions; the chunks of chicken are large, and the excellent gravy will put you in a happy mood

address.street: 2nd Phase, 3rd Stage, Banashankari 7th Block, near Gupta College
2nd Phase, 3rd Stage, Banashankari 7th Block, near Gupta College

content.description: This nondescript last stop before the flyover to Mysore (or the first on the way in, depending on where you’re coming from) is a popular hangout for family crowds. Located on the ground floor of Dev’s Paradise Lodge, the cuisines on offer are Chinese and north Indian. The music is all-out Kannada played at a low volume, and some of the tablecloths aren’t quite the cleanest in the world.The chicken sheekh kababs perk right up after a dash of lemon and the delicious mint-and-coriander green chutney. Blended in yoghurt, this accompaniment was made like it usually is up north. The kadai chicken (a dish dominated by large slices of onion) and the dal makhani (made of black urad dal) are both quite spicy. The FEDA – an acronym for the owner’s names, Felix and his wife Ida – also has a branch in Chandra Layout, should your travels take you to that side of town

address.street: Sri Krishna Temple Road, Indira Nagar
Sri Krishna Temple Road, Indira Nagar

content.description: If she could be plated Sue R John would have been the best dish at this Caribbean restaurant: spicy, sweet and full of goodwill, just like the food she cooks up. The juicy pork curry is mind-blowing and is the star of her Sunday brunch. Apart from the curry, the massive buffet spread includes Jamaican jerk chicken, Trinidad juicy beef stew and fish akra (cutlets). Regulars seek out the geera pork – cubes of the fatty meat slathered in Tobago-style cumin-spiked gravy, served with rice, tomato dal and mother-in-law salad. The spicy salad has a liberal supply of green chillies, thus earning its name.

On the curving far right corner of the not-so-large interiors at Firangi Paani (literally in Hindi: westernised water) is perhaps the only pub wall in town depicting an entire scene straight out of a Charles Dickens narrative, right next to a wall-sized Toulouse-Lautrec recreation. That semi-hideous mural apart, the décor speaks of timidly aligned First War of Indian Independence-era muskets on the wall and random anonymous portrait prints of unnamed white women.A couple of polished barrels down the narrow middle make for a reasonable Anglo-Saxon tavern-like feel of stand-around guzzling, or you could sidle up along the bar counter. The far right corner is clearly too cramped. The evident extra-wax-and-varnish job belies Firangi Paani’s lame shot at a classy affair, though the service is comfortingly Bangalore and unobtrusively laidback; the bar hands may feign initial reluctance, but will soon enough give in to slightly persistent coaxing to serve up off-menu requests with a smile. On the counter, the barman’s babushka shooters are the biggest attraction, especially the flamer (Rs 500), a towering martini glass inferno of rum for you to sip with straws. The Firangi Paani cocktail stirs up cognac and sparkling wine with a dash of Angostura bitters (Rs 450), while the veg-platters make for good starters. Sunday nights are for karaoke, and the music devotedly flips between Bryan Adams and Scorpions, or Pink Floyd sing-alongs. The downside: too little legroom inside - Jaideep Sen

B-52’s groovy, loopy blue sign quite satisfactorily performs the function of a lighthouse on 100-Foot Road in Koramangala – if you drive up from Indira Nagar, it isn’t at all hard to spot this beacon from the Ring Road. Drawing its design cues from every neon-drenched Austin Powers movie, B-52 suggests (at least going by its sign) that inside, you will encounter an explosion of psychedelia. That, however, is far from the case: the black windowless L-shaped room is filled with expansive black leather couches, barstools and pouffes as a nod to modernist minimalism; there’s none of the cotton-candy extravagance of ’60s pop culture. But just when you dismiss the sign outside as an anomaly, you’re confronted by the bar – it is bathed in electric blue light – and the fiery-orange U-shaped tables that you stand at. B-52, it turns out, is an amalgam of two distinct styles, a plangent, two-toned message to Bangalore’s drinkers. The menu contains a wealth of alcohol. The G-spot (`250) – a mix of gin, lime juice, Tabasco, lemonade and fiery green chilli – explodes on your tongue like a cave buster. For a delightful counterpoint, try Boom (`200) which is a mix of apple, chillies and vodka – sweet at first and spicy later. To bring temperatures down to manageable levels, call for the passion cooler (`150), a combination of juices of passion fruit, orange and mango. To attend to your stomachs, try the B-52 platter for two (`250). It arrives stacked with chicken wings, potato wedges, crumb-fried mushrooms and batter-fried prawns. You could choose to remain faithful to your cerveza by calling for the cheese tostadas (`150) – a fried tortilla topped with cottage cheese morsels - Kankshi Mehta

If the dizzying elevator ride up 13 floors hasn’t already thrown you slightly off balance, the drinks menu at 13th Floor will. The cocktails here are organised into various categories, and the “short and potent” section harbours some interesting-looking picks: among others, you’ll find such weapons of destructions as the Uzi, Peacemaker Colt, Tommy Gun and the avowedly patriotic Brahmos (all `300) vying for your attention. Of these, the Brahmos – the Indian cruise missile it is named after is a portmanteau word that combines “Brahmaputra” and “Moskva” – is deserving of its own slot on the Scoville scale: the amount of paprika in this tequila drink will lay you low. The Tommy Gun is a mellow, pleasant concoction, elaborately garnished and sweetened with fruit juice. If you’re not in the mood to experiment, head to sections titled “the usual suspects” and “most wanted”. Pick the strawberry margarita (`375) for some fruity, salty goodness, or, if you’re the designated driver, nurse a Virgin Mary (`185). To accompany this swilling, try the Thai sweet corn cakes (`225): the deep-fried cakes come with a deliciously sweet chilli sauce. For a lighter choice, try the Mediterranean chicken salad (`210). At 13th Floor, you’ll find the music tends towards cheesy ’80s staples of the Bryan Adams variety; it’s only once in a while that a song worthy of a jig will sneak in. But then you don’t come here for the music, or even the food and drink: you come here for the kind of tranquil view of Bangalore you gain only when seated overlooking the city. The outdoor section is almost always densely populated, while the indoor section is near-empty, barring the occasional odd pair that wants to (gasp) converse and not take in the views - Neha Mujumdar

address.street: ISKCON, Hare Krishna Hill, Chord Road
ISKCON, Hare Krishna Hill, Chord Road

content.description: Ah, Mantri Square – that incontrovertible popper of Malleswaram’s mall cherry. And now, residence of Oval Bar, newest entrant to the city’s bar scene. On a bustling Friday evening, we dodged the crowded escalators and made our way up in a no-less crowded elevator to the third floor, where Oval Bar is situated. The bar, it turns out, is really just an enclosure; ergo, one isn’t given the normally expected comfort of having all external activity blocked out. This means that patrons cannot avoid the steady buzz of the mall and, at least on the day we visited, passers-by regularly peered over the fence at the bar, making us feel rather like zoo animals on display. Putting any resultant self-consciousness aside, we examined the menu and ordered ourselves a barman’s special cocktail (Rs.350) and a Long Island iced tea (Rs.400). The first had us intrigued when we saw that it came in an eye-catching bright green, topped with mint leaves, but its cloyingly sweet, bubblegum flavour evoked grimaces. The Long Island, that old failsafe choice for getting as pleasantly and efficiently tipsy as possible, didn’t disappoint: not too sugary or bitter, just bright and restorative. For our second round of drinks, we stopped appreciatively at the long list of whiskeys and single malts – selections in these sections include the Black Dog 18YO (Rs.500), Jura 16 (Rs.550) and the Dalmore 12YO (Rs.550). We chose, however, to go back to the cocktails and pick the Mai Tai (Rs.300), which they make here with sweet lime juice and an amalgam of white and dark rums. The fruity drink brought its trademark rum-spiked tropical goodness to the table and warmly ushered in some weekend wellbeing. For eats, we chose the mozzarella fritters (Rs.125), eagerly anticipating the promised pesto accompaniment; instead, the fritters first came with a gloopy cheese dip. After we requested them for the green stuff, we were given a similar cheesy concoction, but this time with bits of basil minced in. Fair enough, we thought, and proceeded: dipping one dip in another, we found, wasn’t too strange or excessive, and the fritters disappeared quickly. And while the spicy stuffed potatoes (Rs.125) are best avoided (we don’t need more soggy, bland tubers in our lives), the crispy fried chicken (Rs.150) is recommended. Oval Bar may have appeared as a new, strong player in the sparse list of Malleswaram watering holes, but the matter of whether it redeems the traffic-locked, cacophonous monstrosity that is Mantri Mall simply begs another question: how many malls is too many malls? - Neha Mujumdar

address.street: The Leela Palace Kempinski, 23, Airport Road
The Leela Palace Kempinski, 23, Airport Road

content.description: A famous conversation from the 1953 romantic comedy How to Marry a Millionaire goes something like this: Loco Dempsey (Betty Grable): “I wouldn’t mind marrying a Vanderbilt.” Pola Debevoise (Marilyn Monroe): “Or Mister Cadillac.” Schatze Page (Lauren Bacall): “No such person. I checked.” Loco Dempsey: “Is there a Mister Texaco?” Similar thoughts about the usefulness of forging a matrimonial alliance with a man whose bank balance could buy a bank naturally pass through the mind at the ultra-posh Library Bar. Probably because everything about the place exudes the sweet smell of banknotes – right from the dark wood decor that is a throwback to the days of the regency, to the plush sofas, to the wine menu that is separate from the beverage list and is a book in itself (it includes wines which cost Rs.85,000 a bottle). The drinks are usually delivered on small silver trays in personal shakers which are mixed before the table in an elaborate ritual worthy of Veronica Lodge; the accompanying service is extremely attentive. Most of the other patrons may be guests staying at the Leela, which is all the more reason you should keep your un-spectacled eyes peeled, like Debevoise, for Mister Rich.

address.street: Cambridge Road, above Canara Bank, Ulsoor
Cambridge Road, above Canara Bank, Ulsoor

content.description: If you don’t expect anyone dressed like it’s 1999, chocolate martinis or even a playlist that brings back memories of a decade you weren’t born in (expect, instead Coldplay’s “Viva La Vida”) you could be in for a reasonably pleasant evening at Retro. Located above Ruchi Lunch Home, the family restaurant in Cambridge Layout, Retro could well be what a fellow writer termed “a family lounge bar”. It’s a place you could come to with the wife and mum to chat over a drink, or a gang of friends to cheer (or jeer) at Mahi’s men on the plasma TV over several drinks. Alternatively, you might bring a girl here on the eighth date when you’re broke and don’t really care about appearances anymore. The drinks are standard fare and the food is of the Hyderabadi chicken tikka variety, but again, since the menu makes no great promises, you don’t really have anything to complain about. As far as the setting goes, there’s ample space and you don’t feel like the strangers at the next table are going to overhear any of your embarrassing revelations
